title: 4647 Syuji
text:
4647 Syuji, provisional designation , is a dark background <a href="asteroid">asteroid</a> from the outer regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>, approximately in diameter. It was discovered on 9 October 1931, by German astronomer <a href="Karl%20Reinmuth">Karl Reinmuth</a> at the <a href="Heidelberg%20Observatory">Heidelberg Observatory</a> in southwest Germany. The likely <a href="C-type%20asteroid">carbonaceous</a> asteroid was named for Japanese astronomer <a href="Shuji%20Hayakawa">Shuji Hayakawa</a>.
Orbit and classification.
"Syuji" is a non-<a href="Asteroid%20family">family</a> asteroid from the main belt's <a href="Background%20asteroid">background population</a>. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">outer</a> main-belt at a distance of 2.1–3.6 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 4 years and 11 months (1,795 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 2.89 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.26 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 7<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins at Heidelberg on 17 October 1931, or eight nights after its official discovery observation. orbital read
Physical characteristics.
"Syuji" has an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 12.8. Based on the body's albedo "(see below)" and its location in the asteroid belt, it is likely a <a href="C-type%20asteroid">carbonaceous asteroid</a>. As of 2018, no rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Syuji" has been obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations. The body's <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a>, <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">pole</a> and shape remain unknown.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the survey carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a>, "Syuji" measures 13.864 kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="Astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of 0.063.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after Japanese astronomer <a href="Shuji%20Hayakawa">Shuji Hayakawa</a> (born 1958; first name also spelled "Syuji" or "Shūji"), an observer of <a href="comet">comet</a>s and <a href="discoverer%20of%20minor%20planets">discoverer of minor planets</a> at the Okutama Observatory in <a href="Okutama%2C%20Tokyo">Okutama</a>, west of Tokyo. The official naming was proposed by <a href="Takao%20Kobayashi">Takao Kobayashi</a> and the citation was published by the <a href="Minor%20Planet%20Center">Minor Planet Center</a> on 25 May 1994 ().
